title: Synthetic Recap
body:
DETROIT (AP) – In a performance that will be etched into the annals of franchise lore, Joe Dumars authored a masterpiece of offensive artistry, single-handedly dismantling the Boston Celtics and carrying the Detroit Pistons to a gritty 99-89 victory.

On a night when the Celtics' defense had no answers, Dumars was the relentless question. The Pistons guard erupted for a staggering 42 points, slicing through Boston with a surgeon’s precision from every conceivable spot on the floor. He was not merely scoring; he was conducting a one-man symphony against one of the league’s most storied franchises.

While Grant Hill provided crucial all-around support with 16 points, 11 rebounds, and 8 assists, this was unequivocally the Dumars Show. Every time the Celtics threatened to close the gap, the veteran guard responded with a cold-blooded jumper or a driving layup, extinguishing hope with each swish of the net. His backcourt mate, Lindsey Hunter, added 21 points of his own, but even that stellar night was a supporting act to the main event.

Boston, led by Rick Fox’s 22 points and Antoine Walker’s 18, fought valiantly but simply had no counter for the historic onslaught. They were witnesses to a force of nature, a career-defining explosion that left them helpless.

In the end, the final score was almost a formality. The story was the number 42, a figure that echoed through The Palace of Auburn Hills long after the final buzzer. Joe Dumars didn't just win a game; he delivered a timeless performance, a reminder of his place among the game’s greats and a night Detroit will never forget.
